div.p: This paper investigates the problem of secure state estimation for cyber-physical systems (CPSs) modeled by continuous or discrete-time linear systems when some sensors are corrupted by an attacker. A novel state observer is proposed with adaptive switching mechanism. Attack tolerance principle is established based on adaptively truncating the injection channels of attacks. To implement it, a switching function matrix is introduced into the observer design. Driven by a well-defined performance index, the switching function matrix automatically reaches and remains in the desired entry mode and turns off the input channels of attacks. Based on the equivalence between s-strong detectability of the observation error system and 2ssparse detectability of the original system, the observation error system is proven to be asymptotically stable even under the cyber attacks. Compared with the existing complex static batch optimization algorithms, the proposed adaptive observer can be derived only by off-line solving a set of simple linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). Simulation examples are given to illustrate the estimation performance and the computational efficiency of the proposed method.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: With the fast development of science and technology, industrial applications are becoming complex and large. Largescale control systems are present everywhere to sustain the nominal operation of many critical process that we rely on. Cyber-physical systems (CPSs) are a class of more complex large-scale systems, which integrate physical processes, computational resources, and communication capability [1]. However, due to the embedded networked control technique, CPSs become more vulnerable and consequent cyber attacks have become one of the major threats to CPSs. Recently security related accidents indicate any successful attack may lead to significantly hamper the economy and endanger human lives, e.g., the Stuxnet storm [2], the Maroochy water bleach [3]. The importance of addressing the challenge of designing secure CPS has been acknowledged in [4].

Security issues of CPSs subject to external attacks have received increasing attention in the past years. Many important approaches have been proposed to study the effects of specific type of attacks, such as deception attacks [7], [6] and denial of service (DoS) attacks [8], [9]. Recently, the problem of state estimation has been widely studied under sparse sensor false data injection attacks [10]- [13]. For discrete-time linear systems, inspired from error correction and compressive sensing [16], the work in [10], [11] formulates the problem of secure state estimation into a static L r \L 1 , r > 1 optimization problem. The reference [12] further extends the work in [10], and transforms the problem of state estimation into a static batch optimization (SBO) which can be solving by the customized gradient descent algorithms. For continuous-time linear systems, the reference [13] proposes two algorithms that permit the state reconstruction by utilizing the observability Gramian and the Luenberger observer in a multiple model setup. Although these proposed algorithms effectively recover the state, they can be computationally intensive [13] and conservative for deriving convex conditions [10], [12]. In addition, these algorithms also have to be performed for the CPSs under attack-free conditions due to uncertain occurrence time of the attacks.

This paper develops a novel adaptive state observer for continuous or discrete-time linear CPSs with sparse sensor attacks, which works for the system under both normal and attacked conditions. Attack tolerance principle is established based on the direct idea that automatically truncating the injection channels of attacks. A switching function matrix is designed in the observer for searching all attacked sensors, and setting the corresponding output feedback signals to zero. It is shown that the observation error system is asymptotically stable regardless of the occurrence of attacks. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

1) Notions of sparse detectability and sparse strong detectability are introduced in this paper. It is shown that the s-sparse strong detectability of the observation error system is equivalent to that the original system is 2s-sparse detectable.

2) An adaptive switching mechanism is proposed rather than these SBO algorithms. Sufficient conditions for the existence of the proposed observer are given in terms of only solving a set of simple linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). Therefore, the computational complexity is significantly reduced.
3) Using an augmented system approach, it is proved that the observer converges to a neighborhood of the true system state in the presence of sparse attacks and bounded noise.

The notation used in this paper is standard. N + represents the sets of nonnegative integers. ℜ n denotes the n dimensional Euclidean space. C + represent the set of complex number with positive real part, respectively, and C+ = C + ∪ {0}. The notation ∥ • ∥ refers to the Euclidean vector norm. C s l represents the binomial coefficient, where l, s ∈ N + . For a set S, |S| denotes the cardinality of S. Denote by M S ∈ ℜ (p-s)×q the matrix obtained from M ∈ ℜ p×q by removing all the rows indexed by the set S. The support of a vector x ∈ ℜ l is denoted by supp(x), and x is s-sparse if |supp(x)| = s, where s ≤ l.

Definition 5. System (1) is s-sparse detectable if for every set S ⊂ {1, • • • , l} with |S| = s (s ≤ l), the pair (A, C S ) is detectable.
Based on Definition 5, we have the following assumption. Assumption 2. System (1) is 2s-sparse detectable.

In this paper, the objective is to design a state observer for system (1) in the presence of sensor attacks, such that the observer asymptotically converges to the true system state in the absence of additive noise, or to a neighborhood of the true system state under both normal and attacked conditions in the presence of bounded noise.

Motivated by [5], the attack tolerance principle is established based on automatically truncating the injection channels of attacks. We will introduce an adaptive switching mechanism to search for attacked sensors and remove tampered feedback signals.

Remark 1. The considered problem is closely related to fault estimation. However, the literature on [14], [15] typically rely on prior knowledge of the failure models and time evolution of failures, which is generally not available in the context of adversarial attacks.

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, an adaptive observer is designed to estimate the unmeasured states. The corresponding observer gains can be derived by solving a set of simple LMIs. Since the malicious agent intends to inject some cheated information into some sensors to disrupt the estimation performance, it is critical for the observer design to build a switching mechanism to turn off the entries that corrupted measurement signals feed back into the observation. Thereafter, an automatic mechanism has to be developed to locate unknown attack mode S ξ ∈ S and resultantly eliminate influence of the sensor attacks. To implement these, we first define the switching function matrix R ξ(t) = diag{r 1 (ξ(t)), • • • , r l (ξ(t))}, and then the following definition is given. Definition 6. For the ξth attack mode S ξ , ξ = 1, 2, • • • , C s l + 1, the desired switching function matrix is defined as
div.formula: R ξ = diag{r 1 (ξ), • • • , r l (ξ)} where r i (ξ) = 0 for i ∈ S ξ , otherwise 1, i = 1, 2, • • • , l. Further, denote by R = {R ξ , ξ = 1, • • • , C s l + 1}

From the above proof, the effectiveness of the constructed observer depends on that system (1) is 2s-sparse detectable. The limitation implies that it is impossible to correctly estimate the state whenever more than l/2 sensors are attacked. This fundamental limitation is consistent with the previous work [10], [12] and [13].

Remark 2. In [13], a switched Luenberger observer with a finite-time Gramian-based estimator is proposed in a multiple model setup. Such an algorithm is NP-hard in general and computationally intensive. They need to run C s p +C 2s p estimator candidates simultaneously so that the required memory size is O(C s p ) for each time step. In this paper, a novel adaptive switching mechanism is introduced into the observer design. This mechanism can automatically search for the sensor attack mode only by computing online the adaptive law (4). The memory size of the controller is O (1). Therefore, the computation burden and required memory space are both significantly reduced.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, a novel adaptive state observer has been developed for cyber-physical systems under attacks modeled by continuous and discrete linear time-invariant systems. The designed observer is proved to be able to work well no matter wether the attacks occur. Further research is needed to investigate the problem of secure state estimation for nonlinear systems. This is possible with appropriate modifications by following some approaches of fuzzy modelling and fault estimation such as [14], [15]. This will be an interesting topic for future investigation.
